title: RL30432
content: The EPA believes there should be a higher rate of NSR permits for new or expanded facilities. The CAA requires preconstruction review and permits for major modifications or new sources. States with EPA-approved SIPs must approve construction or modifications to ensure compliance with NAAQS. Applicants must demonstrate no violation of NAAQS or exceedances of air pollution limits under PSD regulations. The New Source Review (NSR) process ensures compliance with air pollution regulations by requiring permits for new sources or major modifications that could increase emissions. Sources subject to Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) regulations must install Best Available Control Technology (BACT) to meet federally determined standards. The New Source Review (NSR) process requires permits for new sources or major modifications to ensure compliance with air pollution regulations. Sources subject to Prevention of Significant Deterioration (PSD) regulations must install Best Available Control Technology (BACT) and Lowest Achievable Emission Rate (LAER) if covered by non-attainment provisions. Despite the broad coverage of NSR, few preconstruction permits have been issued to coal-fired power plants. Emissions trends for coal-fired electric utilities have been relatively steady over the last ten years. While NOx emissions have remained constant, there was a significant drop in SO2 emissions in 1995 due to the acid rain control program under the 1990 CAA Amendments. This program required power plants to reduce emissions by about 30% from baseline levels and install Low-NOx burners to reduce NOx emissions. The acid rain control program under the 1990 CAA Amendments required power plants to reduce emissions by about 30% from baseline levels and install Low-NOx burners to reduce NOx emissions. Emissions of SO2 were reduced from 10 million tons in 1990 to 5.3 million tons in 1995, and NOx emissions were reduced by 0.4 million tons in 1996. However, some of the reductions achieved were offset by increases in emissions from other plants, leading to a slippage in overall emissions reductions. While title IV resulted in a 0.4 million ton reduction in NOx by 1996, overall emissions only decreased by about 0.1 million tons. This discrepancy is due to phase 1 not covering all coal-fired facilities, indicating some sources of increasing emissions within the industry. These measures could lead to significant emissions reductions of SO2 and NOx from powerplants named in the lawsuits. The EPA Administrator announced that controlling sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxides from plants could lead to an 85 to 95 percent reduction in these pollutants. This would result in a reduction of 1.87 million tons of SO2 emissions and 0.63 million tons of NOx emissions. These reductions would more than compensate for any erosion in original reductions, with SO2 being reduced by 50% more than the slippage and NOx by about double the slippage. At first glance, substantial emission reductions could be achieved by EPA's NSR action. However, the CAA is complex, with reduction requirements under title IV interacting with NSR reductions. Court of Appeals vacating the new standard for modified utility boilers in 1999.
